title: conor mcgregor dna fathered baby terri murray
story: Terri Murray, , says she gave birth to Clodagh nine months after she allegedly bedded the cage fighter in .The young mum says they had sex at his hotel after the Aintree Grand National – just four weeks before Conor’s girlfriend Dee Devlin, , gave birth to their first child, Conor Jnr.McGregor, worth an estimated £million, has denied he is one-year-old Clodaghs dad and insists that Terri slept with one of his friends.Terri says she does not want money from the former two-weight UFC world champion.I just want to prove he is Clodagh’s dad and I’m not lying,” she told the Daily Mirror.If he gets that DNA test, I’ve said ‘You never have to speak to me again, you can walk away’.”Terri claims she slept with the Irish star after one of his pals invited her to his room in Liverpool’s Hilton Hotel.Social media snaps, which were allegedly taken in the bathroom of his hotel suite, show the pair cuddling up together.In one picture, the fighter’s hand appears to be sliding under her black mini-skirt.Terri claims the star slept with her even though he knew she was not using any contraception.After the romp, Terri said he invited her to another club, but she went home.He allegedly got back in touch two days later and they had sex a second time in the Hilton.When Terri found out she was pregnant, she messaged Conor but claims he did not initially respond.After she gave birth, the mum posted screenshots of their alleged conversations on Instagram – where he appears to claim he is not the father.Last May, Terri filled in an “initial enquiry form” for child maintenance, naming McGregor as the “respondent”.He was recently banned from fighting for six months over a post-fight brawl following his loss to UFC rival Khabib Nurmagomedov.McGregor’s management have been approached for comment.

title: question time no deal brexit
story: The audience member insisted Britain would get through the disruption of quitting the EU without a deal - and find a way to import fresh lettuces from Spain.He insisted reports that supermarket shelves will be empty are just scare stories.The man hit out at lists on the BBC show including Corbyn ally Richard Burgon and Tory minister Helen Whately.He responded to claims that No Deal would make it harder to import fresh fruit and veg from the continent.The Leaver blasted: Youre all limping before you get kicked in a lot of ways.There is a lot of talk about we wont get lettuces into the country, tomatoes and other produce.There is going to be disruption, theres no doubt about that, but in this country we are resilient.We are going to find a way around these problems. Its going to take a little bit of time, there will be some disruption.But we have companies and corporations who have already found ways not to pay taxes in this country - are you telling me theyre not going to find a way to get a few lettuce from Spain to England Remainer businesswoman Gina Miller hit back: Its not about lettuce and tomatoes. Its about agencies and infrastructure and we dont have it.Earlier this week large supermarket warned their supply chains would be disrupted by No Deal.They said they couldnt guarantee that fresh food will be available in the same way as it is now.

title: brits can travel europe no deal brexit eu leaders confirm
story: Ambassadors from the EU have signed off on plans to grant British citizens the right to travel to the continent.The move means that Brits will be able to go on holiday and visit European relatives without any trouble.The proposed rules state that UK citizens can go to Europe for up to  days in any six-month period.Butthey want to stay longer, or to work for pay, they will have to apply for a visa.The British Government has offered the same arrangement to Europeans in the event of a No Deal outcome.The proposal was originally put forward by the European Commission in November.Today diplomats from the  remaining member states rubber-stamped the new rules.They said in a statement: EU ambassadors today agreed that, following Brexit, UK citizens coming to the Schengen area for a short stayshould be granted visa free travel.Now the plan must be approved by the European Parliament before it passes into law.The EU warned thatBritain breaks the promise of visa-free travel for Europeans, they will impose visas on UK citizens in .If there is a Brexit deal, it will include a -month transition period during which the current rules will continue to apply.

title: theresa may blasts eu eurocrats claim gibraltar british colony
story: The UK’s ambassador to Brussels confronted his Spanish counterpart at a meeting in Brussels as a diplomatic crisis erupted.In an impassioned speech Sir Tim Barrow branded Madrid’s rhetoric unacceptable and said it was wrong to call Gibraltar a colony.A source said he blasted PM Pedro Sanchez’s sabre-rattling as “counterproductive” - while Theresa Mays spokesman demanded more respect.And insiders said that even France, which has numerous overseas territories of its own, had come to Britain’s side and also raised concerns at internal EU meetings about Spain’s demands.Madrid sparked the crisis after it exploited Brussels’ No Deal planning to press its sovereignty claims over the Rock.Spain used a simple law, which will grant Brits visa-free travel to the continentthere’s No Deal, to attach a footnote about the Rock’s future.It said: “Gibraltar is a colony of the British Crown.“There is a controversy between Spain and the UK concerning the sovereignty over Gibraltar, a territory for which a solution has to be reached in light of the relevant resolutions and decisions of the General Assembly of the United Nations.”Sir Tim argued the wording proposed by Madrid is incompatible with both the UN position on the Rock and the Withdrawal Agreement between the UK and EU.And he tabled a new clause saying the law wouldn’t prejudice Britain’s legal position on Gibraltar, but it was rejected by other EU states.A UK source said they were “unhappy” with the result but pointed out the text had been softened from a previous draft which called for the “decolonisation” of the Rock.A Government spokesman fumed: “Gibraltar is not a colony and it is completely inappropriate to describe in this way.“Gibraltar is a full part of the UK family and has a mature and modern constitutional relationship with the UK.“This will not change due to our exit from the EU. All parties should respect the people of Gibraltar’s democratic wish to be British.”British officials have been pointing out that the region bordering the Rock, Campo de Gibraltar, is among the poorest in Spain and relies heavily on cross-border trade.But Tory MEP Daniel Dalton fumed: “Spain’s government likes to play politics with Gibraltar when it’s down in the polls.“Surprised that EU officials have made the same mistake. The Rock is not a colony.”

title: pro eu speaker john bercow undermine theresa may brexit
story: The Europhile Parliament chief boasted he was on the side of the dissident minority making le hard for the Government.And he suggested MPs should wield more power over ministers because of the election result which delivered a hung Parliament.Critics accused the Speaker of making it up as goes along after the extraordinary claim.In an interview with CNN, Mr Bercow insisted hes a neutral referee as he presides over Brexit debates in the Commons.But he added: Ive always been keen to give a voice to the dissident minority in the House of Commons rather than in any sense to side with the majority.In a further dig at Mrs May, the Speaker also said: In circumstances where there is a minority Government the Speaker still has and perhaps even more so to be conscious of the need to give the House as a whole the chance to express its will.Mr Bercow dismissed claims hes rude to MPs as a slur from some moaning minister.The Speaker has been embroiled in bullying allegations after former staff accused him of driving them out of their jobs.Tory MP Andrew Bridgen blasted Mr Bercow over his controversial comments.He told The Sun: John Bercow is helping the dissident minority - but where does that leave the democratic majority The Commons has held general debates at a rate of nearly one a week since Theresa May took power.The debates are nothing more than a symbolic talking shop - with no actual decisions taken or laws passed at the end.Since June , there have been  general debates in the House of Commons scheduled by the Government.In the two and a half years before that there was just one, according to the stats from the Commons library.Labours Tulip Siddiq, who commissioned the research, told The Times: Many will be staggered to learn that over  hours of parliamentary time has been spent on debates that have no practical consequences.Next week there are general debates scheduled on pubs and anti-social behaviour.The Commons is not expected to debate Brexit at all next week despite there being a huge backlog of legislation needed to prepare for our EU departure in eight weeks.Bercow has thrown the rulebook out of the window, now hes making it up as he goes along.The Speaker has repeatedly been accused of helping rebel MPs water down Brexit by allowing them to propose helpful amendments while blocking motions tabled by Eurosceptics.He is open about his pro-EU views and is known to have a sticker on his family car saying B*****ks to Brexit.

title: leavers remainers together uk flourish brexit
story: We all want certainty that we will be leaving the EU on th March.  That would enable us all to plan for le beyond Brexit and lead to a period of political calm.The Government’s deal has been rejected by Parliament.  Therefore, leavers and remainers need to come together to develop a new plan so that we can deliver the referendum result and ensure that we flourish outside the EU.This is exactly what we have tried to do with the help of Kit Malthouse. Nicky Morgan, Robert Buckland and Stephen Hammond were on dferent sides to me and Steve Baker during the referendum.  But we have decided to put our dferences aside and unite to publish a new proposal on how we should leave the EU.Leavers rejected the Government’s EU deal because the backstop would have stopped us from agreeing trade deals. So, we have suggested replacing the backstop with a new protocol that solves the concerns people have about the Irish border and which protects the Union of the United Kingdom.Remainers want a guaranteed Implementation Period – a period which allows us all to adjust to le beyond the EU.  Our plan offers a smooth transition with an additional year of the Implementation Period, making it last until no later than the end of December .Parliament, our country and the  member states of the EU are united in wanting a deal and this proposal can pass through Parliament and restore Government unity, purpose and direction.If the EU ignores this consensus, we have proposed a Plan B – a “triple safety net” to protect us.  It includes cooperation on security, a guarantee by the UK of zero tarfs, no quantitative restrictions and no new trading barriers, along with a generous offer to pay our financial contributions infor an Implementation Period.These proposals would allow everyone to prepare fully for the UK leaving the EU and gives us the space to have proper trade talks so that we can develop a close trading relationship  – which, after all, is what Brexit was supposed to be about.Millions of people voted to leave the EU so that we could become an outward- looking, strong, free-trading nation.They also wanted us to maintain the closest of friendships with our allies on the continent, to continue to trade closely with our European counterparts and to let EU citizens - who have become our friends and neighbours and made the UK their home - feel welcome here.We can still be proud of our shared European heritage after leaving the EU but we must do this as an independent nation.This plan gives us a way of doing this and we invite everyone across the House of Commons and the country to support us as we forge a deal that brings the whole country together.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brian reade theres no hope
story: NewsopinionBrian Reade: There’s s-no hope and we’ll all be April Fools with no Brexit dealAll those con men who say us Brits will easily copeour economy falls off a trading clf because we once repelled the Hun from the same clfs at Dover, are living in fantasylandShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  FEB NewsopinionTravelling nightmares may be a bit like Brexit "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Theres a brilliant documentary on Netflix right now called Fyre.It’s about a few grasping liars who sold a fake dream to shythousands of Americans of a festival on a Caribbean island. They shot videos of beautul people partying  , sleeping in luxury chalets, eating fine cuisine and listening to the coolest music. But when the gullible punters arrived, it was a half-finished wreck, with no transport, no musicians and dried-up cheese sarnies for food. America saw it as a metaphor for a selfie generation obsessing on the celebrity dream. But come April ,we leave the EU without a deal, it will be the perfect metaphor for Britain. I don’t speak as a Remoaner pushing Project Fear prophecies of -mile queues at Dover, sick people dying without meds and easyJet planes falling from the sky.   I say it because I sat on an easyJet plane on Wednesday praying for it to take off, but because of this country’s inability to prepare for the slightest disruption, it stayed grounded. I was supposed to be flying from shyLiverpool to Belfast at .am, but due to an inch of snow, took off at .am after a sketch that could have been called Carry On Off The Runway. No one knew what was happening. A couple of workers outside brushed the snow which was turning to slush thanks to the strong sun. Sun which blinded the passengers who had demanded to get off the plane and wade back to the terminal through big puddles on the tarmac.My we rang to say she was an hour-and-a-half late taking our daughter the four miles to school as the roads were unable to cope with the small bit of snow . At least hers wasn’t one of the  North West schools that immediately shut.  When we finally got going, the plane stopped again, with the embarrassed pilot saying the vehicle that was due to pull the de-icer towards ushad broken down. As bemused laughter broke out from those still left on board, he ended his message with “it’s just one of those days I’m afraid”. Funny how, with the slightest bit of bad weather, we always have those days, even though poorer countries with more extreme climates, plan and deal with it. Which is why all those con men who say us Brits will easily copeour economy falls off a trading clf because we once repelled the Hun from the same clfs at Dover, are living in fantasyland. If there’s no deal come April Fool’s Day, we’ll be in chaos, and we will be very, very angry. Welcome to Ire island. Much more tragic than Fyre island.

title: grand national could non starter
story: NewsGrand National could be a non-starterwe crash out of EU with no-dealMany of the jockeys, trainers and thoroughbreds involved in the iconic race are Irish, meaning a no-deal Brexit could cause a problemShareCommentsByStephen White:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsAintree "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA no-deal Brexit could make this year’s Grand National a non-starter with border red tape preventing Irish horses from getting here. Many thoroughbreds, jockeys and trainers involved in the iconic steeplechase at Aintree every April are Irish. Eight Irish-trained horses have won since  – including last year’s   winner, Tiger Roll. Last year’s race had  Irish-trained runners and the nation’s trainers have registered  this year. The British Horseracing Authority runs the Tripartite Agreement, under which horses are moved between us, France and Ireland. What time is Ireland vs England  Six Nations  TV channel and live stream info But our EU exit date of March  is eight days before race day on April  – leaving no time to create a new “equine passport” in the event of a no-deal crash-out. Bookies have slashed the odds of having no Irish-based horses this year from   to  . The BHA’s Ross Hamilton said: “If the UK Government chose to put up borders and tarfs, it would make it dficult for thoroughbreds to move.“It would be a threat to potential Irish horses’ and jockeys’ participationit was a really hard, no-deal Brexit .”George Elek of Oddschecker added: “The Grand National would not be the same without Irish involvement.”

title: baby abandoned london park coldest
story: NewsBaby abandoned in London park was just  minutes old with umbilical cord attachedThe tiny newborn was discovered in a shopping bag next to park bench in a deserted playground in Newham, east London, late last nightShareCommentsByLucy Clarke-BillingsDeputy News EditorIsabel Dobinson:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe newborn child was found crying, wrapped in a towel in sub-zero temperatures "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA baby girl abandoned in the heavy snow was just  minutes old and still had her umbilical cord attached when she was found, it is claimed. The infant has been named Roman by police after the street she was found in. A woman and her son who found the baby said she was purple and cold to the touch. The tiny newborn was discovered in a shopping bag next to a park bench in a deserted playground late last night. She was left in freezing temperatures wrapped in a towel in the bag. According to police, a woman walking her dog past the play area in Newham, east London was alerted to the shivering baby when she heard her cries at .pm. Georgina Player, , who lives around the corner from the play area in East Ham said: The police came knocking at midnight to tell us what happened. They said she was only -minutes-old when she was found - she even still had her umbilical cord.   Shes at Newham Hospital and Im going to go there this afternoon to drop some things off for her - babygrows, milk, anything. I feel so bad for the little thing. She was left in a towel and plastic bag on the ground, next to the bench - not even on it. The police had snfer dogs trying to find a blood trail but they couldnt, which makes me ask how she left in that state. Although it was dark, a lot of people pass through here. You have to walk past to get to the buses. I wish she knocked on the door for help but I think she knew someone would find the baby. Grandmother Rima Zvaliauskiene, , who found the baby, told The Sun she heard a crying noise from a Sainsburys bag for le. She went to investigate, thinking the noise was from an animal. Rima said: “She was crying for her le. The baby saved herself.” Her son Ovidijus, who lives just  yards away, rushed to help. He said the infant looked purple and was cold to the touch. The -year-old added: I would say it was inhumane, to do such a thing, to leave a baby like that. Slwek Pelka, , was walking his German shepherd through the play area just  minutes before the baby was found. He said: Its crazy to think I was there just before, it was totally empty apart from a man sitting on the bench.  When the police and ambulance came, I thought maybe he had died. It was very cold and snowing. A -year-old mother living opposite the empty playground said: I saw the ambulance and police arrive and paramedics running and holding a baby wrapped in a towel. At first I thought it was a stabbing and I was terried. I was the only one in the house with my baby. They blocked off the whole area. It was freezing. It was snowing really heavily. It is really upsetting. She didnt have to leave the baby in the snow and cold, she could have left her on my doorstep and rang the bell. A -year-old grandmother added: My neighbour thinks the poor woman might have given birth there. I really feel for her. She must have been so distressed and she did the best she could. She will have known the playground gets busy and someone will have found her. Police confirmed that the baby girl is recovering in an east London hospital and her condition is now stable.   A police spokesman said: She has been unofficially referred to as Roman after the road where she was found, a small children play area on Roman Road. The child was discovered by a woman walking her dog with her children after she heard the child cry. When found they alerted the emergency services immediately. There were no other people present. Shane Clarke of the north east command unit said: We are growing increasingly concerned for your welfare and I urge you to make contact either with police, your local hospital or GP surgery. story: NewsMums horror burns after passing out on boiling radiator for  minutesWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES: Rebecca Peasgood, , from Eastbourne, East Sussex, felt like she was "on fire" after falling unconscious and landing against the heater which melted her clothes into her skinShareCommentsByHayley Coyle:,  FEB NewsRebecca Peasgood with her partner Ben "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum suffered horror burns and was left scarred for le after passing out on a boiling radiator. Rebecca Peasgood, , was left with agonising third-degree burns after she collapsed onto the heater for  minutes following an epileptic fit. Her clothes had melted into her skin by the time she was discovered. Rebecca was forced to undergo two skin grafts because the first one became infected. The full time mum-of-one, from Eastbourne, East Sussex, was hospitalised for a week and struggled to walk and look after her son. Now, she has been left with a cm-wide scar, and is embarrassed to wear bikinis, she said. Rebecca says: The accident changed my le. I still have flashbacks of what happened.  After years of unexplained seizures, Rebecca was finally diagnosed with epilepsy in February  when she was . In August , Rebecca was recuperating after she broke her leg in a horse riding accident. She said: I felt miserable because I was stuck at home alone. Six weeks after the accident, I was home alone and the heating was on full blast as it was freezing outside. But after a few hours I got too hot, so I changed into thin pyjama shorts. Then I heaved myself into the kitchen to grab a drink. But as I stood up, I felt light-headed and the room started to spin.  Before I tried to steady myself, I collapsed onto the floor. The next thing I knew, I woke up  minutes later to my brother shaking me and screaming my name. Rebecca had landed with her right bum cheek against the radiator which had seared her skin as she lay unconscious. Her brother Harvey Peasgood, , a fisherman, found her on the floor and called an ambulance. Rebecca said: I realised I must have had another seizure. Suddenly I felt an agonising pain in my bum, it felt like it was on fire.  I didnt realise what had happened yet, as I was in and out of consciousness. When the paramedics arrived and tried to remove Rebeccas shorts to check the damage to her bum the fabric had melted into her skin. An ambulance took her to hospital then an hour later she was transferred to a specialist burns unit at Queen Victoria Hospital in Tunbridge Wells, Kent. Rebeccas mum Elaine Petherick, , a carer, her fiance Ben Weston, , a plasterer, and her son Joshua, seven, rushed to the hospital to be by her side. Rebecca said: The doctors gave morphine for the pain, but it wasnt working so I was hysterical. Doctors told me that I had suffered third-degree burns and would be scarred for le.  Every time nurses dressed my wounds twice a day, it felt like they were stabbing me. I was too afraid to look at it in the mirror, I told the nurses I wasnt ready to see it yet. I couldnt sit down, I was forced to lay on my side and my stomach. It wasnt until a few weeks later when I built up the courage to look in the mirror at the damage. All the skin had burned off and there was horrible blisters everywhere. It was the most sickening sight, I was mortied. Doctors told Rebecca that she needed a skin graft and that they planned to take the skin from her leg once her cast was off. A month later in October , Rebecca underwent her first skin graft but, to her horror, it became infected a week later.   Rebecca said: The doctors needed to remove the infected skin and wait for it to heal. The pain was so intense that I was put under general anaesthetic while they cleaned the wound. I couldnt believe I was stuck in hospital again, it had taken over my le. When I ed home two weeks later, I struggled to look after my son Joshua because it was too painful to walk. Three months later in January , Rebecca finally had her second skin graft. Thankfully, it was a success. She says: I was so over the moon. Now today, my bum has healed, and it looks so much better. But the scar has really affected my confidence. I no longer wear bikinis or shorts. I still have horrible flashbacks of that day, it will haunt me forever. Anything that involves heat, like taking a hot bath, makes me panic. Ive even started counselling because of what happened. However, Im lucky that Ben has been so supportive. My scar doesnt bother him at all, it just goes to prove beauty is only skin deep.

title: newborn helps mum discover tumour
story: NewsNewborn baby saves her mums le after sensing cancer in her breastEXCLUSIVE: Claire Granville, , knew something was wrong when her baby Matilda had an unhappy reaction to breastfeedingShareCommentsByLucy Laing:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsClaire Granville with lesaver Matilda "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has survived after her baby daughter SNIFFED out her breast cancer. Claire Granville, , knew something was wrong when her newborn daughter Matilda suddenly refused to feed from her left breast. But she never could have imagined that it could have been anything so serious as cancer.Puzzled by her daughter’s refusal, Mrs Granville went to see her doctor who referred her for tests which showed that she was suffering from breast cancer. She had a massive ten centimetre cancerous tumour sitting just behind her left nipple - exactly where Matilda had refused to feed from. Now thanks to her swt diagnosis, doctors were able to give her chemotherapy in time, and she has managed to beat the disease. Miss Granville, a nurse, who lives in Hull with partner Mark Wright, said: It was as though she had literally snfed it out and was refused to go near it. I thought it was such a strange reaction. She was fine feeding from my right breast, it was just the left one that she wouldn’t go near. She would turn her head away from it as soon as I held her near. It was uncanny to see her reaction to it like that, and it was only because she had done that that I went to see the doctor and it was diagnosed. By refusing to feed from my breast, Matilda has ended up saving my le. Mrs Granville, a nurse, was thrilled when she was pregnant with her third baby. She was already a mother to Jacob, , and Amelie, ten. When she gave birth to Matilda she started to breastfeed her as she had done with her other two children and at first, Matilda fed happily from both sides. But in April , at  months old, she she suddenly refused to feed from the left side. She examined herself and felt a lump there and went to see her GP.  Cold Feet star Fay Ripley shares the lessons shes learnt - and reveals her one regret  Mrs Granville said: The GP said not to worry about it, as they were sure it was nothing.I said I was sure there was something wrong because my baby wouldn’t drink from that side. So they said that they would refer me for an ultrasound just to to reassure me.But when doctors carried out the tests, they discovered she had a ten centimetre tumour behind her left nipple. She said: I was so shocked that I had breast cancer. I knew there must be something wrong for Matilda to refuse to feed from it, but I was so young to have breast cancer. It’s a frightening diagnosis to get when you are the mother of three children. Mrs Granville had an operation to remove her left breast, following by six rounds of aggressive chemotherapy and radiotherapy too.Doctors discovered it had already spread to  of her  lymph nodes, so it was vital that she’d had the treatment when she did. She finally finished her treatment in January when doctors gave her the all clear, and she was able to ring the bell on the hospital ward to signy the end of her battle. She said: It was a very emotional day when I rang the bell. Everyone is rooting for you, so to be able to ring it like that is an amazing feeling. I’ve heard that animals can sense when their owners have cancer, and it was as though Matilda could sense it in me too.There was a reason why she wouldn’t feed, and I’m so glad I trusted her instinct that something was wrong. Because I was able to get treatment swtly, then it meant that my treatment has been successful. If I hadn’t listened to Matilda then it may have been too late when I was treated. It had already started spreading when I was diagnosed. One day when she’d older I’ll tell her how she has ended up saving my le.

title: nurse tells tragic stories child
story: NewsThe Language of Kindness: A nurses story of the child patients who moved her to tearsEXCLUSIVE: Christie Watson, who became a nurse at just , has written a memoir of some of her most touching and distressing memories in her fieldShareCommentsByRachael BletchlyOliver Milne:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen Christie Watson took up nursing at the age of  she spent a lot of time shycrying.She cried when she messed up her first injection and when a patient suffering schizophrenia became violent as she took his blood pressure . She wept when she saw her first dead body and, after witnessing a dramatic birth, sobbed so hard her student unorm collar was soaked with tears. But after two decades working in mental health, paediatrics, neonatal care, AE and ICU, Christie’s tears dried up. She says: “I was becoming emotionally numb to quite shocking events. I thought I’d got compassion fatigue.You become harder with every bit of cruelty you witness and I coped by shydeveloping a sick, sarcastic sense of humour. “But there was always a patient who’d remind you of someone you loved and open you up again.” Many of those patients feature in Christie’s best-selling memoir, The Language of Kindness, A Nurse’s Story.  It’s a poignant, powerful and shyemotional account of her -year career, but also a timely reminder of the sacrices made by her shycolleagues on today’s front line. Christie, , says nurses are facing “a perfect storm” of challenges that threaten the future of the profession and the NHS. She adds: “It is shyunbearably hard for nurses today. “They are the most undervalued of all professions and morale is lower than ever. We’re , nurses short in England alone, applications have dropped because the Government scrapped the bursary which paid for their training. “Nurses will be qualying with massive debts and harder to keep in the profession. So who is going to deliver the NHS’s  Year Plan  “The NHS is not failing. Nurses are not failing. They are BEING FAILED.” Christie, from London, is a single mum to two children aged  and . She came off the nursing register last year and now writes full time and fights for staff as Patron of the Royal College of Nursing Foundation. In her book, she recalls some of the patients who left a lasting impression... especially the youngest ones. Here are just three of their stories. Charlottes story Two-year-old Charlotte has shymeningococcal sepsis . It can kill a child within hours. She is en route to the PICU [paediatric intensive care unit] and we get everything ready. She arrives on a trolley covered in tubes already, a ventilator at her head end and a monitor by her feet. Charlotte has no blood pressure. It is impossible to cannulate her, as her veins are too dficult to find.  Her leg is cold and pale, like a twig from a dying tree. We manage to resuscitate Charlotte and attach her to even more machines. But the purple rash has spread. I know when I hand over, long after my sht should have ended, it is unlikely that Charlotte will be there in the morning. She’ll need three nurses just to care for her and she’ll probably lose her almost completely dead and purple legs, and possibly her arms, too. Children as sick as Charlotte have such a profound physiological shycompensatory response to illness that they shut down any part of their body that is non-essential. Charlotte has kept her blood for her vital organs and has taken everything she can from her limbs. But Charlotte is not done yet. Her body is fighting internally as much as our machines are fighting externally. This will to survive, this powerful and physical defiance of death, is one of the reasons I’ve always loved working in children’s intensive care. Still, before I leave, one of the doctors says: “We might need to amputate. Get the surgical team up here. It might save her, might not.” I look at the nurse taking over from me, who will likely hold shyCharlotte’s leg as it is cut off on the ward. She is fairly junior and already this week has had to pull a mother off a child who died, the mother trying desperately to give him chest compressions after the team had stopped. The surgeon will come and remove Charlotte’s leg. Then leave. The amazing paediatric intensive care doctors will spend  minutes explaining what is happening, and why, to the family. Then leave. The nurse will hold Charlotte’s leg as it is being cut off. Then she will sit with Charlotte’s parents through the entire night, performing her nursing tasks, as they ask her a million questions... “Is she in pain  Will she walk  Can she hear me  Is she dying ”  Charlotte should have died a hundred times over. She loses her legs and her fingertips. The extent of her illness is beyond the capabilities of our shytechnology. Yet she survives. And Charlotte’s will to survive lts all of us. It is easier to do the job with shychildren like her. Easy to find the energy to be kind and to care, to prioritise, as do all nurse-parents at times, another child – a stranger – over our own. And when Charlotte comes back to see us two years later, toddling on shyprosthetic limbs, smiling, looking well, holding her mum’s hand and chocolates for the nurses, we all stop whatever we are doing and crowd around. I think of all the sunsets Charlotte will get to see. The golden skies. “Thank you,” her parents repeat over and over again. “Thank you.” And I suddenly feel. I feel so deeply that I have to hold my breath. Charlotte is truly alive, and so am I. Tommys story Tommy does not want to see the sun. He closes his eyes whenever I open the curtains, and screws his face up tightly. Tommy is nine years old and shyparalysed from the neck down, following a road traffic accident. I look after Tommy for many shyconsecutive nights over many months. Twelve-and-a-half hours when it’s often simply me and him. Tommy has spiky black hair, which his dad puts gel in every morning. Next to his bed is a small table with a photograph of Tommy, his mum, dad and cousins on holiday, drinking through long curly straws from coconuts. I wonder what he was like before. I provide all this physical care for Tommy, but it is his mind that needs nursing most of all. We talk through feelings. ‘I am not surprised,’ I tell him, when he mouths that he wants to go home. ‘I think I would feel the same. You must really miss the time before the accident.’ I understand his desire to go home is a desire to travel back in time to his old le. He is not talking about a physical home. I read to Tommy that night, and many others when he can’t sleep, his eyes open too wide in the near-darkness. We read Harry Potter and, as the story develops, his eyes close a little: he escapes a fraction. He requires ventilating, his broken neck means he can no longer breathe unaided. He has such complex needs that it may take many months before he gets out, years even before he gets to his physical home. I listen to his mum and wonder how on earth she will cope when Tommy’s dad is working away. She also suffers with depression.   Tommy’s th birthday arrives while he is on the ward. The nurses decorate his bed space with tinsel leftover from Christmas, stick up cards and balloons. But under the stark lights of the shyintensive care ward everything – even le – seems articial. Tracy, one of the nurses, brings in some flowers from her garden. Tommy looks at them but then closes his eyes. Tracy loves him. She talks to him all day, as she washes him, rubs cream into his skin, stretches his legs out, the radio in the background. She dances, terribly, punching her hands in the air. It is the only time I see Tommy laugh. There is a mound of presents at the bottom of Tommy’s bed and his dad has a large sack of gts when he walks in. “There’s the birthday boy.” He kisses Tommy’s face and they smile at one another. He starts pulling out presents one by one and piling them on the bed until Tommy is wide-eyed. When Tommy falls asleep his parents stay on the ward. “He wanted a bike,” his mum says. “I always promised him that he’d get one on his th birthday”. Her body folds in half. She holds her stomach. “I’m so sorry,” I say. The tears I am holding in burn my eyes. Tommy’s dad puts his arm around her and squeezes. “It’s temporary. He’s a fighter,” he says. “I know he’ll walk again. I just know it, love. Doctors get things wrong all the time.” He looks over at Tommy, who’s asleep surrounded by equipment and machinery. Then he turns to me and nods that slow nod you do when you want someone to agree with you. But all I can do is push my razor blade tears even further back and fake a smile. I look away, and focus on Tracy’s wild flowers. Jasmins story Jasmin is a -year-old girl on a ventilator, following a house fire. Her hair smells so strongly of smoke that we are reluctant to allow her family to see her. Jasmin’s brother lies a few beds away, also on a ventilator but weaning off it, less sick, stronger. Their mother is dead. Jasmin is sedated and dying, but her aunt is now waiting to come in and see her. The ward’s usual smell of antiseptic has been replaced with that of fire. Nurses cover their mouths and noses with gauze swabs. Someone asks for theatre masks. We cannot make things any better for that poor family, but smelling the lingering smoke will surely make it worse for Jasmin’s aunt.  Sometimes not making it worse is all we can do. Jasmin is so sick that it is dangerous to move her at all. But I hold her head very carefully, as my colleague Nadia washes her hair as best she can. That smell will stay with me for ever. It enters my nostrils and rests somewhere much deeper in my memory. As I hold Jasmin, I feel a change. Nothing changes on the monitor. The ventilator does not alarm. But Jasmin has changed. She feels lighter in my hands – something has shted. Her head is a feather. I look up at Nadia, who is looking back at me and we both understand Jasmin has died. We do not move for a few seconds. Take a pause. Then we both go back to the task, Nadia pulling a thick combthrough Jasmin’s soapy hair, tipping water gently over her. I hold Jasmin’s head, letting the blackened water fall between my fingers to the plastic bucket we’ve put underneath us. I take the bucket to the sluice and tip it away, and the smell of smoke fills me up once more. I close my eyes and envisage the block of flats: Jasmin and her brother sharing a room, and their mum trying desperately to get to them. I hear screaming. Smell fire. I push tears back, make my stomach hard. It is not a time for me to cry.   The priest is half an hour away. There is no time to wait. I discuss what we can do, for Jasmin’s aunt. She does not ask about my faith, but instead about my experience. ‘Have you done it before ’. Jasmin is not the first child I have christened. We keep some holy water in the PICU in case a child is dying, the parents have not yet christened them and the priest is unlikely to make it in time. I find myself putting my fingers in the water and making a cross on Jasmin’s head. If there is a God, he will surely forgive me, I tell myself. Patients like Jasmin stay with me for ever. I carry the smell of smoke. Extracted from The Language of Kindness by Christie Watson, published by Vintage at pound..copy Christie Watson .

story: NewsParents to be told to limit childrens screen time to two hour sessionsChief Medical Officer Sally Davies is set to issue guidance next week but will apparently stop short of proposing a cap on technology useShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror lestyle health video much-screen-time-stunt-childs-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailParents are reportedly to be told to officially limit their childs screen time to two hour sessions. Next week it is expected Chief Medical Officer Sally Davies will issue guidance to parents about encouraging their children to exercise or play after tech-time. The Department of Health have reportedly stressed Dame Sally will not propose a daily cap on the amount of time children use such technology. She is however expected to point towards a possible ‘association’ between social media use and mental ill health, before calling for more research into the issue.  It comes after an academic blamed Instagram for the suicide of her -year-old daughter and father Ian Russell revealed his daughter Molly, who took her own le at , looked at images glorying self harm on the social media site.When Matt Hancock replaced Mr Hunt as Health Secretary, he asked Dame Sally to fast-track her findings and come up with guidance that could become a ‘norm in society’, similar to the recommended maximum alcohol consumption for adults. In October, he said: Unrestricted use of social media by younger children risks being very damaging to their mental health. It comes as the schools minister Nick Gibb said Mobile phones should be banned from classrooms. Mr Gibb said he had concerns about the impact that excessive phone use was having on children, and said the Government would introduce lessons for pupils on how to limit their screen time.   Speaking to The Times, Mr Gibb said: Schools obviously are free to set their own behaviour policies but my own view is that schools should ban mobile telephones and smartphones inside school, and particularly inside classrooms. I believe very strongly that children should be limiting their own use at home. Every hour spent online and on a smartphone is an hour less talking to family, and its an hour less exercise and its an hour less sleep. And of course it is a lack of sleep that research is showing can have a damaging effect on a childs mental health.

title: prince harry gets parenting practice
story: NewsPrince Harry gets in parenting practice as he meets adorable kids with Meghan MarkleThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex are expecting their first child in the spring - and they were keen to meet a group of adorable youngsters waiting in the snow for them in BristolShareCommentsByAmber HicksRussell Myers:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video harry-adorable-bird-impression-children-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Prince Harry looked every inch the perfect father-to-be as he greeted some of his youngest fans in freezing temperatures in Bristol today. The Duke, , made sure to stop and chat to the adorable nursery school children who gathered waving flags to meet the prince and his we Meghan, .Meghan giggled: They are very good at waving flags. Harry was also heard joking to the nursery staff about how they keep them all under control. He mischievously added to the youngsters: You know you guys can run anywhere you like  as he bent down to check they werent too cold. However, some of the three and four-year-olds from Abbeywood Tots appeared to be more excited by their snack of digestive biscuits than their brush with royalty. Harry later asked: Are you nice and warm in here  as he admired one of the children’s snowsuits.  Meanwhile, he also shook several of the youngsters hands and did funny impression.Nursery worker India Leachman, , said after the meet and greet: “The children beckoned them over, like ‘we’re excited to see you’, waving their flags and as soon as they came over, they were interested in their biscuits. “They looked very interested in all the children and making sure they were warm and thanked them for coming out.” The Duchess also stopped to admire one little girl’s plastic tiara and princess dress, which she wore under a zipped up snowsuit. The couple, who travelled  miles from Kensington Palace, were greeted by a winter wonderland after the area was hit by flurries overnight. They were forced to cancel their plans to fly because of the bad weather and arrived in Bristol by train, about half an hour later than planned. Meghan wrapped up warm in a pound, silk-chfon midi Oscar de la Renta dress, vintage William coat and pound olive leather boots by designer Sarah Flint.  She teamed the outfit with a matching olive clutch bag that she took to Prince Louiss christening. And she appeared to be wearing her pound -karat gold Pippa Small Herkimer diamond stud earrings that she was spotted in at Princess Eugenies wedding.Harry looked dapper in a jumper and blazer.Although they had been delayed, the pair were met with a warm welcome by throngs of well-wishers - including students off school because of the weather - eager to catch a glimpse of the VIP visitors. Meghan told fans: We tried our best to get here fast. She later apologised and said Sorry my hand is cold.  One member of the public told Meghan how her now-defunt blog The Tig had been an inspiration to her. The Duchess also chatted to another fan about yoga and how it was relaxing for the mind, body and soul. She added: A nice practice would be so fantastic right now. All hands were on deck before they arrived to grit roads and try and make the slippery, slushy streets safe. The aim of todays royal engagement was to learn more about the citys cultural history and visit organisations supporting communities most in need. Police earlier revealed they had stepped up security and put up barriers to keep crowds at bay. Chief Supt Ian Wylie, from Avon and Somerset Police, said: Of course the Duke and Duchess of Sussex are the A-listers of the Royal Family and it will attract lots and lots of visitors. As well as the politan Police royal protection officers, well have many of our own local officers supporting.   The visit began with Meghan and Harry being taken on a guided tour of the Bristol Old Vic theatre, which recently underwent a multi-million pound restoration. While there, the Duchess spoke to the children about the benefit of arts and theatre extracurricular activities as a creative outlet. Some of the children then performed an extract of Shakespeare play King Lear before Harry and Meghan unveiled a plaque.The Bristol Old Vic was built in  and has a unique place in British theatre history having nurtured the talents of countless famous actors from Daniel Day-Lewis and Greta Scacchi to Peter OToole and Jeremy Irons.   The internal layout has been transformed, with the restoration of the Georgian Coopers Hall, a new studio theatre created in the old barrel vaults and mezzanine galleries. The project is the second stage of a -year pound million programme to completely overhaul and safeguard the future of the theatre. As the couple left the Bristol Old Vic a member of the crowd shouted: Harry can you take these flowers to which the Prince ran and got them.Obviously they are for my we and not me, he said as he thanked the woman and ed to the car.The pair also visited Empire Fighting Chance, a charity using boxing to support children failing at school and in danger of drting into a le of unemployment or even crime.   Two pairs of personalised black and white boxing gloves baring their names in gold were waiting for the couple as a gt.They met young people using the gym, spoke to coaches about the positive impact boxing is having on Bristols youngsters, and watched a couple of training sessions attended by primary and secondary school pupils. The couple then head to One, a charity specialising in helping women to break free from street sex work, addiction and other le-controlling issues. It is the third royal engagement on the week for Meghan.Yesterday, the Duchess visited City University as patron of the Association of Commonwealth Universities . And on Wednesday, she stepped out in a stunning pound, outfit for a visit to the National Theatre. Meanwhile, staff at the hospital where Kate Middleton gave birth are reportedly on alert ahead of the next royal babys arrival. It had previously been reported thatMeghan may potentially give birth on the NHS at Frimley Park hospital, just a stones throw away from her new home Frogmore Cottage .But she could now follow in the footsteps of Kate after all by giving birth on the luxurious Lindo wing in St. Mary’s Hospital, in Paddington.“Staff at the Lindo wing have been asked not to take holiday in April,” a source told the Daily.“Everyone thinks it’s got something to do with the royal baby but no one is confirming anything.”

title: prince harrys comforting private chat
story: NewsPrince Harrys comforting private chat with boy who broke down over dads deathThe two spoke when Harry and his we Meghan Markle visited the Empire Fighting Chance charity in Easton, BristolShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsPrince Harry visits the Boxing Charity Empire Fighting Chance, in Easton, Bristol "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCaring Prince Harry comforted a teenage boy who got emotional talking about the death of his father. The Duke of Sussex, who lost his mother Princess Diana when he was , spent  minutes talking privately to -year-old Iestyn Jones about processing his grief. He told the teen: “The same thing happened to me.” Realising that the young lad needed some space, he asked aides and workers at a boxing club in Bristol to leave the room while he comforted young Iestyn. Harry, , has spoken previously about how taking up boxing gave him an outlet for aggression while he was struggling to cope with his grief and on the brink of a nervous breakdown when he was younger.   The two spoke when Harry and his we Meghan Markle visited the Empire Fighting Chance charity in the tough inner city neighbourhood of Easton in Bristol. Iestyn from Kingswood near Bristol said: “It just got a bit emotional because he mentioned something. He knew some stuff about me and the same thing happened to me. We had a chat for about  minutes.   “When we had a group picture at the end he made sure I was standing next to him. They were lovely people. I didn’t expect them to be like that. They were amazing people.” Based at a boxing club that trains amateurs and has produced professionals including former IBF bantamweight world champion Lee Haskins and ex-IBF world featherweight champion Lee Selby, Empire Fighting Chance uses boxing to help troubled young people drting into a le of unemployment or crime. The charity, based in a former sports centre that was earmarked for closure in  when Bristol City Council was forced to embark on budget cuts, is funded by a mixture of Lottery money, corporate sponsorship, grants, and the charges it levies on schools for pupils using its facilities.   The charity was started in  by Martin Bisp and Jamie Sanigar after they spotted two youths dealing drugs outside their boxing club in the nearby neighbourhood of St Paul’s and invited then into box to get them out of trouble. “Within six weeks we had  kids coming in twice a week,” Mr Bisp said. They now run programmes for  young men and women per week combining non-contact boxing with therapy, numeracy classes, and other courses designed to instil discipline, self control, and respect while building self confidence and improving physical and mental health.

title: super rare used ford car
story: NewsOld Ford racer is going for a whopping £, in an eBay auctionEXCLUSIVE: This Ford is an "extremely rare" RS rally version - and its had thousands of views on eBayafter it was postedShareCommentsByJeremy Armstrong:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBack in the s, you would have expected to see a Ford motor on the school run, or down the local shops.Now a -year-old model is on sale for pound, on the auction site eBay. But this is no ordinary car.The extremely rare RS was made for the Group B class of the off-road racing competition, what is today the World Rally Championship Fewer than  of the promised  cars were actually built and most have since been written off or modied. Welsh car restoration specialist Ramsport placed the Turbocharged .-litre, left-hand, four-wheel-drive collector’s item on eBay, and it has already attracted thousands of views.  “This fully original Ford RS rally car, Chassis number , has just undergone a full mechanical refurbishment, they tell would-be buyers. “As one of the most original examples of an RS, this car is almost unrivalled in the quality of its condition and originality. The Group-B competition formula cars were banned in .This sale model was sold to Christian Jaquillard in Switzerland, before a collector in the South of France bought it in , and it has barely been on the road since. Ramsport’s Office Manager Dominic Spiller told how the RS seller also had a MGR which they have comprehensively restored on sale - for a cool pound,.  It is the rarity of the RS  that makes it so eye-catching, he said. The group B rally series was widely seen as the golden era of rallying. With very few performance and design restrictions, the cars were twice as powerful as they are nowadays.You had to sell a road version, and had to sell at least .The big cars of the era were the MGRs, the Audi Quattros, the Peugeot  Ts, and the Lancia s. The Quattro was taken from the road and changed for rallying, but Ford did the rally car first. The RS is the rarest of them all, and this owner has a passion for motor sports. He has thrown money at this and his R to make sure they are as good as they possibly can be. title: mum discovers having twins nurse
story: NewsMum discovers she is having twins when nurse stitching her up spots second headNicole Ziesemer, , from Michigan, US, said doctors were stunned when she delivered her first baby but continued to feel pain as something  was in thereShareCommentsByHattie BishopLucy Clarke-BillingsDeputy News Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsNicole and Matthew, from Michigan, US, are delighted with the two new additions to their family "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA first time mum discovered she was having twins when a nurse trying to stitch her up spotted a second head. Nicole, , and Matthew Ziesemer, , had only just been introduced to daughter Blakeley when doctors realised the new mum was still in labour. Medics caring for Nicole spotted another head during a post-birth clean up and baby Cade was born  minutes later. During her pregnancy, Nicole only had one scan - the day she went into labour. And it is thought Cabe was not spotted as he was hiding behind his sister. Nicole, from Grand Haven, Michigan, US, is now home and delighted with the two new additions to her family. The -year-old, who worked in insurance before becoming a mum, said: It was crazy. We were over the moon but it utter shock. There were really no signs that I was carrying more than one baby, in fact people said how small I was. We thought the biggest surprise was going to be the sex of the baby, little did we know. It was really scary when they said that something  was inside me.  She continued: And when they told us that it was another baby I literally asked hershe was lying. I just couldnt take it all in and was still in so much pain that it was almost impossible to process. But I really cant imagine having just one baby now. Its like they were meant to be. I love the thought that theyll always have each other. Nicole planned a natural home birth with just a midwe present but had to go to the nearest hospital - Gerber Memorial, Michigan - when her waters broke at just  weeks The new mum - who had severe morning sickness throughout the pregnancy - decided to forgo painkillers in favour of breathing exercises, a yoga ball and cool showers. She did not have any scans throughout her pregnancy, apart from one on the day her waters broke, because she wanted a natural pregnancy. But after being in labour for over  hours, the expectant mum opted for an epidural and a suction.   Blakeley arrived two hours later at .pm on December  weighing lbs oz. But doctors grew worried as instead of the pain subsiding, Nicole was still in agony after the delivery. They were due to stitch Nicoles vagina up but realised something  was in there, Nicole said. While medics were trying to retrieve her placenta, it became clear something was not quite right and decided to do an emergency ultrasound. Nicole gave birth again  minutes later, to a baby boy, weighing lbs. Baby Cade, who was having dficulty breathing on his own, was rushed straight off to nearby Spectrum Hospital, in Grand Rapids, Michigan, USA.   Nicole, who stayed with her daughter, said: Over the next few days my husband was primarily with Cade while my daughter and I stayed in for observations. We were still reeling from the shock and just trying to get our heads around it all. But primarily all we wanted was for them both to be strong and healthy. The craziest thing is that on the day I went into labour I did have a scan but it only picked up the one baby. They think that Cade must have been hiding right behind his sister. When they were allowed home the couple, who met online in , went shopping for duplicates of all the baby equipment they had previously purchased for just one.  Matt, a chiropractor, and Nicole have since been told that twins and triplets run in her side of the family. She said: It was amazing to hear that its a bit of a family tradition, my grandmas cousins apparently had twins and triplets. People do ask uswe were to have another baby would we have scans this time  but I honestly dont think we would. Unless there were any clear medical red flags, Id do it just the same all over again. Matt added: It was truly was just such a surreal moment. I could not believe that my we was carrying two children that entire time. My we does an amazing job with the two of them. I really dont know how she does it all day every day.

title: worlds oldest woman who didnt
story: NewsWorlds oldest woman who didnt enjoy single day in long le dies aged Koku Istambulova said she did nothing special to live so long and was laughing with her grandchildren when she diedShareCommentsByWill StewartKelly-Ann Mills:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video worlds-oldest-woman-aged--,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman believed to be the oldest person to have ever lived has died aged . Koku Istambulova, a survivor of Stalin’s repressions, would have turned  in June, according to accepted pension records in Russia. She was older than a woman listed in the Russian Book of Records who died last month supposedly aged , officials believed. Koku made headlines last year by saying she had never lived a single happy day in her long le. Her grandson Iliyas Abubakarov said she had supper as usual on Sunday, January  at her village home in Chechnya.   “She was joking, she was talking,” he said. “Then she suddenly felt unwell, she complained of a chest pain.“We called the doctor, we were told that her blood pressure had dropped, and injections were made.“But they failed to save her. She died in a quiet way, fully conscious, praying.” She has been buried in her home village Bratskoe, survived by five grandchildren and  great grandchildren. A Muslim who was born before the last Tsar Nicholas II was crowned, she outlived the Soviet Union by a generation, according to her internal Russian passport. Her date of birth was claimed to be  June  - when Queen Victoria was on the throne in Britain. But her passport gave only a year of her birth, not the exact day and month.   In extraordinary and moving testimony broadcast last year she spoke emotionally of the appalling day her native Chechen people were deported en masse by Stalin to the steppes of Kazakhstan  years ago. She told how people died in the cattle-truck trains - and their bodies were thrown out of the carriages to be eaten by hungry dogs. If her age was correct, Koku was  at the time, having earlier lived through the coronation of the last tsar Nicholas II two days before her th birthday - and his toppling when she was . “It was a bad day, cold and gloomy,” she said of the February morning in  when the entire entire nation was banished from their mountain homeland in the Trans-Causacus. “We were put in a train and taken … no one knew where. “Railway carriages were stuffed with people - dirt, rubbish, excrement was everywhere.” Stressing the cruelty of Stalin’s action, she told journalists determinedly in her native Chechen language: “Write that - there was excrement in the carriages.   “We were not allowed [to go] anywhere.” Young Caucasus girls died because from the rupturing of their bladders - they were ashamed to go to the toilet in crowded stinking the crowded trains. Older women tried to crowd round them to stop their embarrassment as they relieved themselves. Yet there was worse. “On the way to our exile, dead bodies were just thrown out of the train,” she said. “Nobody was allowed to bury the dead. “Corpses were eaten by dogs. My father-in-law was thrown out of the train in this way.” A paranoid Stalin had alleged the Chechens were collaborating with the Nazis. “We were told that we were bad people and thats why we had to leave,” she said. Before the war, she recalled “scary” Nazi tanks passing her family home. She suffered devastating personal bereavements in her Kazakh hell - her two sons both perished in the harsh conditions. “There were no doctors, no-one to treat them,” she said. “My younger boy came down with something and passed away really quickly.   Such things happened in every family. “When women gave birth children often died because there were no obstetricians, only neighbours and friends.” Weeping the old lady said: “I only kept my daughter Tamara.” She was exiled in Kazakhstan for  years then, after Stalin’s death, people were allowed toto their homeland. When she got back, many houses had been grabbed by incoming Russians - so she set to work building her own home, complaining her husband was too lazy for the work. She conceded that despite her earlier claim, the day she moved into her own house, built with her own hands, after ing from internal Soviet exile was “happy”. “I built it myself, the best house in the world,” she said. “I lived there for  years.” Asked about the secret of going le, she previously said: “It was God’s will. “I did nothing to make it happen. “I see people going in for sports, eating something special, keeping themselves fit, but I have no idea how I lived until now.” Her recipe for a long le was fermented milk, but she shunned meat and soup. She asked: Why did Allah give me such a long le and so little happiness .... “I would have been dead long ago,not for Allah who was holding me in his arms.” Koku said: “It is hard to live when all who remembered you died long ago. And it is very scary to die, however old you are.” The oldest documented human was Jeanne Calment, from France, who lived  years,  days, dying in . French scientists have dismissed a recent claim from Russian researchers who argued she assumed the identity of her dead daughter and was not as old as records show.

title: dundee uniteds nicky clark says we are making life very hard for ourselves
story: Nicky Clark admits Dundee United are “making it very hard for ourselves” as their bid for promotion to the Premiership stumbles yet again.The Tangerines fell six points behind leaders Ross County and three behind Ayr United after losing to the Honest Men - last Friday.With  matches remaining in the Championship race, Clark admits the Tangerines need to pick up three points more often than not between now and the end of the campaign.And that starts this weekend at home to Greenock Morton.The striker said: “We’re still up there, still round about it but we know we need to pick up now.“The next game is massive for us now, we need three points because we are making it really hard for ourselves but we need to just concentrate on our own matches and it’s important we pick up three points from most games between now and the end of the season.“There is still plenty of time, especially in this league because everybody seems to beat everybody, but it’s games like Friday you need to go and winyou want to win titles.“Friday we didn’t manage that so we only have ourselves to blame.“However, we have Morton this weekend and we can galvanise ourselves and get three points.“Saturday will be tough – it’s all good teams in this league so we need to prepare ourselves this week. The gaffer will get us ready for it and we need to make sure we go and do the business.”The performance at Somerset Park was a bitter disappointment for the  United fans who made the long trip on a Friday night.And Clark admits it wasn’t good enough from the Tangerines.He added: “We went down to Ayr with full intentions of winning the game.“We gave ourselves a chance a couple of weeks ago against Dunfermline when we won and got ourselves up the league but we let ourselves and the fans down on Friday.“The weather meant it was never going to be a pretty game and they got a chance early on and took it.“I think we only had one real chance with Aidan towards the end where the goalie was out quick and made a good save.“All in all it was a very frustrating night and we were very disappointed.”Strong winds made le dficult for all the players but it was clear Ian McCall’s men coped far better with the conditions than United.The home side dominated the opening period and got their goal through Craig Moore early on but the expected response from the Tangerines with the wind in their favour in the second half never really materialised.Clark added: “It was dficult conditions but we’ve all played in wind like that before, we all know what it’s like.“We had a game plan – I don’t knowwe didn’t stick to it but it never happened for us.“We’re disappointed because that’s nine points we’ve given Ayr this season and we’re making it very hard for ourselves.”It’s been a stop-start first season at the club for Clark with a series of injuries curtailing his first-team opportunities.Now, though, he says he’s back to % and ready to help United get back on track.“It’s been very frustrating for me, I’ve missed a lot of games with daft wee injuries here and there where you can’t actually treat them, you just have to leave them until they get better.“It’s been frustrating but I’m back and feeling good now so, hopefully, I can kick on now and help the team get where we want to be.”

title: tom duthie dundee united need to start performing in the big games
story: Despite the major disappointment of the defeat at Ayr United, the consolation for Dundee United fans at the moment has to be the fact they have become genuine promotion contenders under Robbie Neilson.The gap to the top of the table has stretched to six points again because of that Friday night loss at Somerset Park coupled with Ross County’s victory over Alloa on Saturday afternoon.It can’t be forgotten United’s poor goal dference effectively means right now the gap to the top is seven points.With just  games to go, time is also running out for United to make up the lost ground and clinch promotion at the first time of asking.Boosted by the January signings that are set to continue in the final few days of the window,they can gel quickly enough, Neilson will believe the deficit can by clawed back and, in a Championship race that’s seen every team drop points regularly, even a decent winning run could do that.The manager’s overall record since he arrived in October does also give some reason for Arabs not to give up hope just yet.Since his debut win at Partick Thistle in mid-October, with , his team are the leading points gatherers in the second tier.By beating Alloa in Dingwall on Saturday, County took their points tally over the same period to  and while no one would argue the fact promoted Ayr are having an excellent first campaign back at this level, they have been showing signs of running out of steam.Between their hugely impressive - win at Tannadice right at the end of November and their repeat success over United the other night, Ian McCall’s team had gone five league games without a win and also, of course, suffered that humiliating Scottish Cup exit at the hands of juniors Auchinleck Talbot.If that, and the points tally under the new manager, provides encouragement, what continues to be a major concern for United is their poor record against the others at the top end of the table.Friday was their fth clash with the top two on league business and, to date, the record reads played five, lost four, won one, score two and conceded .Add to that a League Cup loss up at County in July and what you have is a worrying statistic.Without wishing to paint an even darker picture, they have also only drawn two clashes with Inverness with both coming when the Highlanders were sitting in one of the promotion play-off places.If they are to realise American owner Mark Ogren’s dream of going up automatically during his first months in charge, it’s a statement of the obvious to say the big-game record has to improve drastically.Should it, United can still get to where they want to be. They’ve two games to come against County and one final crack at Ayr and, of those showdowns, two are at Tannadice.Yes, the two heaviest defeats of the season came there against County and Ayr but under Neilson that second defeat was the only one he’s suffered in seven home games so far.And last time he sent out a team to face County he did mastermind what was without doubt the best win of the campaign to date, a gritty - success on their patch, in November.If the manager can mould his rebuilt team over the next few weeks, wins like that one can be repeated.They’ll have to be, or United’s big-game failures will see them negotiating even more vital outings in the play-offs.

title: celtic-blow-as-tom-rogic-out-out-valencia-game
story: Celtic have been dealt another injury blow with Tom Rogic ruled out of this months Europa League tie against Valencia. The Australian midfielder is looking at a six-week lay-off with knee ligament damage which he sustained while on international duty at the Asian Cup. Ironically, Rogic ed to Celtic earlier this week with a hand injury which the Parkhead side sent him to London to seek specialist advice, That problem appears to be fine but scans revealed a knee problem which will sideline him now. It comes on the news this week that Filip Benkovic is also out until March at the earliest, while Kieran Tierney also looks highly unlikely to make that one given that he has yet toto full training with an ongoing hip and pubic injury. "Tom Rogic will be out for about six weeks," confirmed Rodgers. "Tom obviously has come back from the Asian Cup. He did his hand out there, which it was felt didnrsquot need an operation but he still felt pain in it, and then he got injured in one of the games out there and his knee was a bit sore. "When he ed we had a plan for him to go to London for a scan just to make sure his hand didnrsquot need an operation. "When he was down there we got a scan on his knee and it ended up that the knee was the one! Hersquos done his lateral meniscus so he needs an operation next week. That will put him out for about six weeks. And his handrsquos ok! Therersquos always somethinghellip
