title: Clachnacuddin FC pays tribute to superfan from Yorkshire
story: Bronwyn Wain , who lived in Huddersfield, was described as a ldquolovely lady and ldquoreal character by club figures.Despite living in Yorkshire, her unlikely association with the club began in  when she got in touch with the Lilywhites out of curiosity about the clubrsquos name and history.The links grew from there and she became a true Lily when she visited Grant Street as club guest in . Her husband John, who passed away a few months ago, joined her.ldquoThey were a lovely couple. Just ordinary folk who took the club to their hearts and they became well-known to many of our players, directors and fans, said Billy Corbett, a former director of the club. ldquoIt was the name Clachnacuddin that attracted her attention. Its a Gaelic word and means lsquothe stone of the tubrsquo. But when she got in touch we responded by sending her a hat and scarf and some programmes.ldquoShe was absolutely thrilled and kept in touch through Facebook checking results and encouraging the team. She sent money every month to one of our fans to buy her ticket in the Lily Lotto. She had so many friends the club had a whip round for her and her husband to visit.During the trip they attended a Clach game against Strathspey Thistle , which the Lilywhites won - ndash a result which left the couple ldquotickled pink. Former director Jim Oliver also showed them round town and on a cruise down Loch Ness.ldquoI donrsquot think they had ever been to Scotland but they got a real taste of Highland League hospitality, Mr Corbett added.Following her death the couplersquos son Michael passed on his heartfelt thanks to Clach fans and officials for all they had done for his parents.Jim Oliver said: ldquoA lovely lady whom the Clach Facebook followers got to know very well. All in all she was a real character.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Disused Daviot tourist site set for regeneration
story: A FORMER Culloden Academy pupil who has set up his own care business is to bring new le back to a former tourist office on the A just south of Inverness.Tim Cockinghopes to create up to  new jobs in the care sector and is looking for an operator to run a restaurant cafeacute type business from the former Visit Scotland office at Daviot.Formerly known as the Daviot Woods picnic site he is renaming it the lsquoNorth Gatewayrsquo.ldquoItrsquos right off the A and a perfect location for travellers passing through Inverness perhaps going to do the North Coast , said Mr Cocking who left Culloden when he was  with his family to live in Edinburgh.ldquoIrsquove seen the building when Irsquom visiting the north and itrsquos been looking rather sad and dilapidated and I thought there was something I could do with it.Mr Cockingrsquos Edinburgh-based company Brightcare has now applied to Highland Council for permission to change the use of the building to incorporate restaurant and retail facilities.ldquoThere once were public toilets there and itrsquos my intention to reinstate these once we have a thriving business on the site.His company Brightcare provides private home care for private clients looking for an alternative to residential care and already employs six people in the Highlands.ldquoWe have our HQ in Edinburgh and employ  people Scotland-wide and six of these jobs are in the Inverness area. But it is our intention to grow that business to about  jobs in the next few years.ldquoThe building at Daviot would also have an office for Brightcare. Itrsquos a well known building, bigger than we need for an office and there is space for both operations.ldquoI have already had expressions of interest from restaurant operators and a dog grooming business which would fit in well to because it is a popular area for people walking their dogs.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: DJ marathon charity event in Inverness aims to be a money spinner
story: Several local DJs will take to the decks during the Caledonian V Cancer event this Saturday in aid of CLIC Sargent.The music starts at pm and finishes at am on Sunday, and the sound selectors will include DJs Terry Fire, Lady Beats, Andy Innis, CKaz and Richard Lewis.The event has been organised in memory of Michael Murphy who succumbed to cancer last year aged .Michaelrsquos uncle Sean , of Dalneigh, is a regular in the bar.Sean has already organised several fundraising events across Inverness, and so far he has raised more than pound for the charity.Sean said he was really grateful to the Caledonian and all the DJs for their support, adding: ldquoMichael first became unwell in  and he had two forms of leukaemia and sadly died last September.ldquoCLIC Sargent really helped us through some hard times so I became involved in the fundraising.Michael was involved in last yearrsquos Stand Up To Cancer campaign on Channel  having been filmed for the national fundraiser prior to his death.The former factory worker and McDonaldrsquos crew member lived in Forres before moving to Inverness.Mark Glendinning, general manager of the Caledonian, said: ldquoWe try to support as many local events as possible, but this one is particularly special as Sean is both a friend and regular customer.ldquoCLIC Sargent is a wonderful charity that supports cancer patients and their families during incredibly dficult times.ldquoThey were particularly helpful to Michaelrsquos we Shannon and young daughter Sophia after he passed away, so we want to help Sean raise funds for them to give something back.CLIC Sargent supports children and young people with cancer and leukaemia and the Caledonian event will be held ahead of World Cancer Day on Monday.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Game group boosts Highland Hospice coffers
story: Sixteen members and guests of the Borlum game shooting syndicate, Scaniport, managed to more than double a total raised last year, with local businesses also helping with donations in kind.The group staged a three-course bothy lunch, an extensive auction of donated goods and a series of competitions including th century musketry, a clay pigeon shoot and retriever dummy-throwing.More than  auction items donated by members and guests ranged from home-made honey and tablet to malt whiskies, artworks and several hundred kilos of firewood.Local businesses added support, including outdoor specialists Grahams, which chipped in two daysrsquo trout fishing, Highland Industrial Supplies and Allans of Gillock with tools and workwear, Harbro with a retail voucher, Tesco with food and Scissor Sisters of Dingwall with haircut vouchers. Scaniport Estate made a direct donation of pound, to bring the total raised to pound.Borlum farmer Alan Fraser, who was auctioneer for the day and whose we Yvonne and others produced the meal, said: ldquoIt was a great effort by all, an enjoyable afternoon and a huge thousand-pound increase on the pound raised last year. We all appreciate what a tremendous personal service the Highland Hospice provides for our community, and that it costs about pound a day to run, so every small event and contribution helps.Highland Hospice community fundraiser Katie Gibb added: ldquoI would like to say a huge thank you to everyone who organised and participated, as well as the businesses who supported it. To raise nearly pound is just fantastic and will be appreciated by those who rely on our care.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Highland air traffic controllers to be balloted over strike action
story: The Prospect Union has already notied Highlands and Islands Airports Ltdthat it will be asking air traffic controllers to cast a vote regarding a strike. An indicative ballot in October gained overwhelming support.The dispute centres on the controllers at Inverness and where being paid much less than their counterparts further south, which the union maintains is unfair.An innovative centralised air traffic control system that many fear could lead to job losses in years to come has also added to the bitterness in the dispute, though it is not part of the current move.Before Christmas both Prospect and HIAL agreed to an evidence-based business case that set out the pay gap between HIAL and the rest of the industry in an attempt to resolve the dispute.Prospect believesHIAL cannot attract and retain controllers through pay issues, this has and will continue to cause staff shortages and pose a risk to maintaining service provision.According to the union it has no choice but to move towards industrial action after Scottish Ministers rejected the business case earlier this week without explanation and with no additional funding offered.Prospect negotiation officer David Avery said: ldquoScottish Ministers have been promising pay restoration for public sector workers but their policy fails to deliver.ldquoThere is a global shortage of air traffic controllers which is driving wages up across the industry - at the same time HIAL staff have received below inflation pay awards.ldquoIt is unfair that a HIAL air traffic controller, providing an essential service for the Highlands and Islands, is being paid half as much their counterpart in London ndash enough is enough.ldquoOur members have tried every other means to resolve this dispute but by rejecting a fair and reasonable proposal to resolve the dispute ministers have left them with no option but to pursue strike action.HIAL HR director Andrea Sillars, said: ldquoHIAL note the position taken by the Ministers. We are disappointed that Prospect have decided to ballot their members on strike action. We remain committed to continuing constructive discussions to help resolve the dispute and are open to holding further talks with Prospect on a recruitment and retention allowance for Air Traffic Control staff. We await the outcome of the ballot.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Highland Council vows to continue dialogue after 3300 SNAP petition submitted
story: Worried parents handed in a -signature online petition to the council today in an effort to save Special Needs Action Project .Later following a meeting between council chief executive Donna Manson, council officers and Snap manager Dawn Walker and Snap board chairman Donald Robertson, the council issued a statement saying it recognises ldquothe very much valued support this organisation provides to families in Inverness.Ms Manson said: ldquoOfficers are continuing dialogue with Snap to identy other possible sources of funding to help achieve a viable position. We will be entering into early discussions with Snap and other third sector organisations regarding need, service requirements and formal processes to allocate funding. There will be a workshop in February with members of the third sector, including SNAP, to agree methods of funding and how we can redesign our processes.She added: ldquoOur discussions have been useful and I have given a clear commitment from the council that we will work with the third sector to help lever funding from where as we work together for the benefit of all Highland communities.Ms Walker said: ldquoWhile the meeting was more positive, we are still in a position of not knowing what is going to happen.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness Airport hotel plan takes off
story: The Courtyard by Marriot will be situated within Inverness Airport Business Park and it set to open its doors later this year.Owned and developed by Molo Hotels, the property will be operated by the independent hotel management company RBH.Chief business development officer at RBH, Andrew Robb, said the company is delighted to be working alongside Molo hotels and Polcom Construction for the project.ldquoWersquove forged a strong working relationship with Molo Hotels and Polocom Construction over the years and are thrilled to be working with them on what promises to be another outstanding property, said Mr Robb.The -bedroom hotel plans include meeting and fitness facilities as well as a bar and bistro.Contractor Polocom Construction has started the production of bedrooms in Poland before they are transported to the site near Inverness airport in May.A spokesman for RBH has said that the hotel is set to be open by the end of the year: ldquoWhile we canrsquot give an exact opening date at the moment, the hotel is scheduled to open in quarter  of  she said.Molo Hotels changed their name from Polocom Developments in .Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: New bridge over the River Nairn is on track for summer
story: TEMPORARY weight restrictions on a busy rural road could be scrapped by the summer.Work to build a new crossing over the River Nairn to replace the ageing White Bridge is ldquoprogressing well and on track for completion by early summer, Highland Council has confirmed.The road bridge, which dates back to the th century and is category A listed, spans the river on the B route between Clephanton and Cawdor.It has been struggling to cope with heavy modern traffic and a weight limit of  tonnes has been in operation while a new bridge is built and the road realigned. The weight restriction has caused disruption for farmers, forestry vehicles and tour buses, which have been unable to use the existing bridge in the interim.The pound. million project is being handled by Dingwall-based RJ McLeod .Confirming that work is on track, Highland Council said that construction of the abutments for the new crossing beams was now complete and the beams were successfully hoisted into place this week.Now that the four beams are in place, contractor RJ McLeod will proceed with decking out between beams in preparation for concrete casting.Highland councillors in the Nairn and Cawdor ward, and Culloden and Ardersier wards ndash whose boundaries are spanned by the new crossing ndash have welcomed the progress being made.During the works the existing route has remained open to drivers, however all road users have been reminded about the -tonne weight restriction.Any vehicles which weigh more than this limit should use the ersion route, which goes via the A, A and B roads.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: New Lochardil hotel owner pledges to make investment
story: NEW owners of a well established Inverness hotel have promised more investment to make it even more attractive to visitors.Lochardil House Hotel has become the second mainland hotel bought by Skye-based Perle Hotels and the group has been advertising for staff to get ready for the summer.The Victorian mansion, which was built in  as the home of Inverness MP Charles Fraser-Mackintosh, has been a hotel since .It was previously owned by Eileen Fraser, who bought the hotel in . More recently she has expanded the hotel with the addition of a purpose-built banqueting suite, a conservatory restaurant, new kitchens and a separate  bedroom garden wing, more than doubling its accommodation provision.Perle Hotels marketing manager Nina Ghita said the group wanted to build on the hotelrsquos heritage and had no plans to change its name.ldquoWe want to keep those unique quirks and the history. Those are really important, but there are always things that can be improved, she said.ldquoWe focus on the Highlands and Islands and we invest quite heavily into the hotels, provide more jobs and just try and make something special within the area. The same thing will be happening with Lochardil. Obviously the hotel is in a really good position as it is. We donrsquot have any concrete plans as yet, but there will be heavy investment down the road.Unlike the grouprsquos previous hotels, which required major renovations, she does not anticipate anything so drastic. There are no immediate plans to add other north hotels to the group, but Ms Ghita pointed out there were opportunities available all the time.ldquoWe are a growing company, she said. ldquoThere will be future expansion plans but nothing concrete at the moment.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: One man campaign to safeguard cyclists
story: Allie Middletonfrom Balnakyle Road is concerned about the visibility of a cycle path which cuts through trees and merges with the east junction with Lochy Road and he is urging locals to campaign for improved awareness and traffic calming measures.ldquoI just happen to live opposite the cycle track. I would never be able to forgive myselfsomething happened and I hadnrsquot done something about it, said Mr Middleton.He is particularly concerned that many drivers do not know the cycle track is there because it is set back roughly  metres from the road, through the garden of the Green Drive Hall.Mr Middleton said when the cycle path was upgraded three years ago, a barrier was removed which had separated the path clearly from the road.There is now a sign at the end of the path before it meets the road, warning cyclists to dismount. But Mr Middleton said that the sign was being ignored and there was a danger at the bend where cyclists meet traffic.Speed reducing tables have been installed at the site, but Mr Middleton said: ldquoCars are going over the raised tables at mph and then drivers are putting the foot down in between them.He has reported his concerns to the council who carried out a survey in May last year. It revealed the average speed in the mph zone at the busiest time in the morning is .mph.He is now urging the council to instal signs to alert the drivers to the oncoming cyclists or a speed indicating devicewhich will show road users their speed.The path is used by pupils from Lochardil Primary, Inverness Royal Academy Holm Primary and the Gaelic school.Mr Middleton fears young people on the path may not be seen by fast moving vehicles: ldquoWe have crossed this road many times andin the company of two or four of my grandchildren this is more dficult, the main reason for this is in estimating the speed of accelerating vehicles since the tables were installed said Mr Middleton.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoA mph zone was recently installed in the Culduthel Lochardil area at the request of the community council. The scheme which encompasses Balnakyle Road includes appropriate signage and associated traffic calming features. Highland Council are monitoring speeds and will be making the police awarea persistent speeding problem is demonstrated. The concerns... will be investigated.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Parents criticise new school bus service across Inverness
story: SCHOOL bus services have been in chaos since a council contract changed hands at the start of the month it has been claimed.Parents say a move to double up dedicated school runs with services for the general public since transport giant Stagecoach took over the Highland Council schools contract from DE Coaches on January  has seen pupils regularly forced to endure late-running and dangerously overcrowded buses.Police have also confirmed they are investigating allegations that pupils were threatened with a weapon on board a bus between Kirkhill and Charleston Academy on January .Mum Carol Paterson, whose daughter travels from Croy to Culloden Academy, said the problems are known about across Inverness.ldquoThe children at Croy are waiting sometimes up to  minutes in freezing conditions because the buses are now regularly late, she said.ldquoAnd when they board the bus there are not enough seats.Jools Lawson, whose daughter attends Charleston Academy, said: ldquoKids are regularly having to stand on a jam-packed bus or being put off altogether and told to wait for another one.ldquoThe service is disgusting and Stagecoach brush our complaints under the carpet.Posts from a private Facebook group set up for parents of pupils using school buses and shown to the Inverness Courier make clear the extent of unhappiness since the changeover.Other alleged incidents include children being put off a bus beside a busy main road without a pavement and two incidents involving Inverness Royal Academy pupils ndash one where a bus did not turn up at home time and another where the bus was too small to accommodate them.Highland Council has issued two separate statements in response to concerns raised ndash one with regard to a public service operating en route to Inverness Gaelic Primary stating it is unlikely to involve ldquoroutes which the public are likely to want to use and another on the Charleston Academy-Kirkhill route stating ldquomeasures have been put in place to make improvements.Despite this an online petition has been launched calling for the reinstatement of dedicated school services.Signed by almost  people so far it states: ldquoWhen putting our children on a school bus it used to be the case that it was only school children on these buses, therefore anyone travelling was accounted for and any incidents easily dealt with and tracked.ldquoNow we have opened the floodgates to allowing our children to be exposed to anything on these buses.Councillor for Culloden and Ardersier, Glynis Campbell-Sinclair, said Highland Council needs to launch its own investigation into whether there is a serious problem with how buses taking pupils to and from schools operate.ldquoThey cannot jam pack children onto buses like pilchards and hope there is not going to be an accident - especially in this weather, she said.ldquoEvery parent that sends their child to school by bus is depending on the council to ensure that happens safely.ldquoIt is the councilrsquos responsibility as corporate parent to ensure these children get to school safely.A spokeswoman for Stagecoach North Scotland said: ldquoSince we started operating the additional school contracts on January  there have been some issues with capacity we have identied and are working to resolve.ldquoWe are working closely with Highland Council to resolve these problems by issuing school children with passes allocating them to specic buses to prevent the overloading problems we have seen.She added that in terms of the issues raised by Mrs Paterson an additional bus is now running to and from Croy.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Site for Inverness homes not acceptable
story: Councillor Ken Gowans hit out at the application by agent Bracewell-Stirling for DMPM Services.He said the site was not zoned for housing and would pile pressure on local school rolls which are already well over  per cent capacity.ldquoWhile we need more affordable houses, any development must be part of the local plan, and this development is not.ldquoThis is likely to generate more unacceptable pressures on infrastructure which is already struggling to cope at the moment.ldquoWhile developers pay contributions towards education, it doesnrsquot change the fact that local schools are beyond full, and the councilrsquos school roll projections indicate these will worsen in the short to medium term, he said.Highlands MSP and road safety campaigner David Stewart also expressed some concern: ldquoI am mindful that the dual A will be at one side of this site and the rural B road will extend along another side of the site.ldquoAs it stands, this particular road has no pavement for pedestrians and this would be an issue that would cause me concern.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Work starts on new outlets at Eastgate Shopping Centre
story: WORK has begun at the Eastgate Shopping Centre in Inverness to develop four food outlets.The units, suitable for restaurant or bar operators, are being created by the reconfiguration of two existing shops fronting Falcon Square.Burger King UK is the first operator to sign up while talks are ongoing with operators for the other units.In addition, a new kiosk will be created fronting the Falcon Square mall entrance. Possible uses include an outlet for a food takeaway.The development comes as the cityrsquos nearby rail station is set to undergo a pound million upgrade while a public consultation is currently ongoing into a bold vision to transform Academy Street to make it more pedestrian-friendly.Alasdair Murdoch, chief executive of Burger King UK, said: ldquoWe are excited to expand the Burger King brand in Inverness and look forward to welcoming guests to experience the great-tasting, high-quality food that has delighted Burger King customers for  years.Local building and construction company Compass expects to hand over the units in late May to be fitted out and managing director Thom Macleod is delighted it has been appointed principal contractor for the redevelopment of the former Monsoon and Mamas and Papas unit.ldquoHaving been involved extensively in the planning of the project, it is pleasing to now be making preparations for the works to get formally under way on site, he said.Previous proposals involved an extension into Falcon Square or rooftop bar but were altered to attract a wider range of operators.Centre manager Jackie Cuddy said it will be business usual while work proceeds.ldquoWe are delighted to see the works progressing after several enforced delays over the yearsshe said. ldquoThe market may have changed since we first started out on this journey but we are still optimistic that we can provide a great addition to the night time economy of Inverness with this development.Saturday  Feb  : AM

story: A volunteer group set up to help people in an emergency has welcomed a public consultation to alleviate flooding in their community.Residents in Inverurie and Port Elphinstone are to have their say on a flood scheme appraisal study next month.Aberdeenshire Council appointed Dougall Baillie Associates and JBA Consulting to carry out the report for the area.The firms will also be looking at flood studies for Ellon and Insch, with a focus on the flooding caused by Storm Frank in .Community leaders in Inverurie have called on residents to share their knowledge with consultants.Members of the public have been invited along to the public consultation taking place on February  at Inverurie Academy from  until pm.Councillor Neil Baillie, who is part of the Garioch Resilience Group, said: “We don’t know any of the points the public consultation might bring up at the meeting or how many options there might be.“After Storm Frank, anything that can stop us getting into that situation again is welcomed.“The consultants have been working hard to get this information together and are at a point they can put in some realistic approaches to see how flooding could be mitigated.”Cllr Baillie added: “The Garioch Resilience Group is based on volunteers in the community for how best we could respond to an emergency.“We work alongside the local authority and the emergency services.“Any aspect of this consultation that looks into flood improvement for our rivers or coastlines, and can mitigate flooding in the future, would be welcomed in the community.”Councillor Judy Whyte, who represents Inverurie and District, said: “Specialist consultants appointed by Aberdeenshire Council are holding a series of public consultation events.“They will gather data for a flood appraisal study to identy options for a plan to manage flood risk.She added: “It is important the consultants receive as much local knowledge as possible, particularly from those who were affected by the extreme flooding we experienced in Inverurie and Port Elphinstone in .“I’d encourage anyone with an interest to attend and input to the process.”

title: doctors sent north east woman home with two zimmer frames and walking sticks but she had to get back to the gym
story: A woman who woke up in the middle of the night having lost the ability to move and speak today told how she got her le back through fitness.Fiona Halliday, , was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis in , but around three years ago she woke up during the night and found she was unable to get out of bed.She said: “It was petrying. I woke up and wanted to stand up from my bed and I couldn’t.“I couldn’t walk or speak, so I went to ARI and the doctors could tell something was not right.”Fiona said doctors admitted her for a brain scan, thinking she had suffered a stroke.She added: “I had all the symptoms. The left side of my face was dropped and I couldn’t talk.”After multiple tests, the doctors told Fiona and her family she had developed a very rare form of MS called tumefactive MS – the condition causes all the symptoms of a stroke and Fiona now has a non le-threatening brain tumour.Fiona said: “It was very scary because we didn’t know what it was for a long time. I wasn’t able to hold myself up, I had trouble balancing when I would try to walk, I couldn’t even hold a spoon to feed myself – it was awful.”Before the incident, Fiona was a fitness instructor and the condition temporarily took this away. But now, with time, it has been a major motivation to getting her back on her feet.Supported by her two children, David, , and Gemma, , and her husband David, , Fiona was on the road to recovery.She said: “For me, the biggest thing in my le was the gym and I had that taken away from me.“Fitness had always been my passion – and I knew I had to get back to it. My friends would tell meI went to the gym I would die.“The doctors sent me home with two Zimmers and walking sticks.”Determined not to use them, Fiona started walking every day for  minutes to build up her strength.With the help of doctors, neurological physiotherapy, occupational therapists, speech therapists and a personal trainer, Fiona has made major strides in her balance, walking and co-ordination. vw, px"  A year ago, she was able to join The Unit gym in Banchory, where personal trainers help her to train. “It has taken me three years to get here and the journey felt like a long one,” she said.“But it’s a big dference from three years ago – and I even just got my driving licence back.“I was down and picked myself back up.”Fiona continues to struggle with her speech because of the mass pressing on her brain, but will not be discouraged.She said: “Everyone can do something to better themselves, evenyou’re diagnosed with a horrible condition you shouldn’t give up.”Now, she hopes to give back to the charity MS Society which was there for her during the dficult times. Fiona will be taking on the zipline challenge of  metres through trees in Crieff near Perth.

title: first aberdeen homes connected to new fibre broadband
story: The first homes in Aberdeen have been connected to a new fibre broadband network.CityFibre is undergoing a revamp to ensure every area can connect to full fibre broadband.It has invested more than £ million into the project which will make Aberdeen Scotland’s first gigabit city.Aberdeen City Council co-leaders Jenny Laing and Douglas Lumsden joined with CityFibre bosses earlier in the week to see the construction process first hand in Torry.A second civil engineering firm, Actavo, has been appointed to help deliver the initiative.Allan McEwan, development manager of CityFibre for the city, said: “Aberdeen was the first Scottish city announced as part of our national rollout to bring full fibre broadband to five million UK homes and businesses.“It is fantastic to see it coming to le with the first homes now beginning to connect.”

story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowIt#s time to celebrate the birthday of Robert Burns.In Tayvallich, Burns# best-known song will be celebrated in pioneering Scottish musician Mairi Campbell#s one-woman theatre show, Mairi Campbell: Auld Lang Syne.The show tells a very human tale through Mairi#s personal relationship with the world-renowned song, including forgetting the words when singing for President Clinton and featuring in the New Year’s Eve scene of the  movie Sex and the City. With live music, animation and movement, this potent, funny and heartfelt show uses Mairi’s own experience to create a piece that resonates with wider universal truths.Mairi opens the show with a short song set and during the interval a haggis stovie supper will be served, including a vegetarian option. To help them know how many tatties to peel, could you please let organisers knowyou#re coming along to the event on Saturday February  and how many are in your group by contacting Ewan Halley at ewan@ehalleyMairi Campbell is a pioneering Scottish musician whose work is rooted in her personal stories and cultural concerns. Since studying classical viola at the Guildhall School of Music, she has become an established member of Scotland’s traditional music scene, pushing the boundaries with her use of free improvisation, songs and stagecraft. Mairi is the recipient of several national music awards. Her first solo show Pulsehas gained much critical acclaim and has toured widely.

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: brave mcdonalds worker hailed hero
story: NewsBrave McDonalds worker hailed a hero after rescuing a gran from fireLewis Macdonald, , battled back flames and thick smoke to save the le of Nan MarshallShareByAbi Smillie:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsLewis saved the le of Nan Marshall. "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave McDonald’s worker has been hailed a hero after rescuing a gran from a burning home. Lewis Macdonald, , battled flames and thick smoke to save the le of granny-of-three Nan Marshall from a blaze which broke out in her living room. The sht manager was driving past -year-old Nan’s home on Castlehill Road in the early hours of New Year’s Eve when he saw flames flickering in the window. A Las Vegas neon sign – which Nan popped on for the festivities – had caught alight. Quick-thinking Lewis, along with pal Lauren Kennedy, sounded the alarm, got Nan to safety and dampened the fire with towels before the fire brigade arrived at the scene.Lewis told the Ayrshire Post : “The whole night was a blur.“We were driving back from work and I saw a fire in the window. “I was chapping on the door and ringing the doorbell. “The full house was covered in black smoke. “I couldn’t see anything. “I didn’t know how long the firemen were going to take and the house was still on fire so I thought I needed to do something. “Nan was shook up about it. “I was trying to get into the kitchen because Nan said there were towels at the washing machine. “They were pretty damp so I just threw them over it. “After we put the fire out, we sat on the wall and waited for thefiremen. They had a big extractor fan and they were trying to get all the smoke out.“It had even got upstairs, the firefighters said.” Nan was upstairs sleeping at the time unaware as to what was going on. She said: “I wondered what it was. “I could hear the doorbell and by this time the smoke alarm kicked in. “Luckily I woke and came down the stairs and there was my hero at the door. “Buthe hadn’t of been here I would’ve been a goner with the smoke alone. “Even now, anything you touch you’re covered in black soot. “I was in a state of shock. “The table caught fire and the windowsill. “I had to go to the doctor two or three days later because I kept wheezing.” Daughter Lesley Watson, , added: “It could’ve been so much worse –Lewis just caught it in time. “If that young man hadn’t been passing, she wouldn’t be here today.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr NewsAyr

title: driver who sped 70mph through
story: NewsDriver who sped at mph through streets of Troon is jailed for  monthsMark Kirkby almost killed his passenger when he finally crashed into a wall following the high speed chase.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsMark Kirkby was jailed for the reckless driving"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who drove like a maniac through the streets of Troon has been jailed for  months, writes Edwin Lawrence. Mark Kirkby, , almost killed passenger Kerrie Anne Monaghan when he finally crashed into a wall. Miss Monaghan was in Ayr Sherf Court on crutches to hear the sentence on her partner, who she is standing by. The court heard Kirkby did not even have a driving licence and Sherf John Montgomery banned him from holding one for four years. Depute fiscal Lindsay Bain told the court police spotted a silver Volvo being driven erratically from Barassie Street into Portland Street. The police car’s blue lights went on and Kirkby initially slowed down before increasing speed. He was hitting mph in Templehill before heading into Harbour Road. And Kirkby’s car was said to have taken off as he drove across a mini roundabout into Port Ranald Drive. He hit mph in North Shore Road, eventually crashing into a wall at the Beach Road Kilmarnock Road junction in Barassie. During the whole episode, which began around .am on October  last year, Kirkby drove dangerously through junctions and swerved round corners.  When the crash occurred the car’s airbags were deployed but this did not prevent Ms Monaghan’s horric injuries. She had to be cut out of the car by firefighters and suffered numerous fractures to her face, head, body and limbs. “Kerrie Anne Monaghan is very lucky to be alive,” said fiscal Ms Bain. The court also heard of offences committed by Kirkbywhose address was given as Barlinnie Prison, on June . This time he was in a grey Ford Mondeo around .am when police spotted the car stationary on the A near the Pennyburn Roundabout. Kirkby was unsteady on his feet and slurring his speech, although a breath test proved negative. A a blood test found substances identied as cocaine and benzocaine. Defence lawyer Hugh Duncan said Kirkby’s relationship with Ms Monaghan was still ongoing. “He accepts full responsibility,” said the lawyer. “He comes across as remorseful to the injuries his partner suffered and to potential harm he could have done to others.” Mr Duncan said Kirkby had been remanded in custody since October , had undergone a detox programme, and had come to a realisation of his mental health issues. Sherf John Montgomery told Kirkby: “You drove dangerously at high speed for an extended period. I see no option but a custodial sentence.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnHMP BarlinnieVolvoAyrCourtsJusticeTroon

title: elliots prestwick evolve rebrand vics
story: NewsElliots in Prestwick to "evolve" with rebrand as Vics  The VineBosses at Buzzworks say the bar and restaurant must "evolve" as part of its transformation.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB NewsBuzzworks managing director, Kenny Blair, is promising bold changes at Elliots "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of Ayrshire’s biggest hospitality venues has closed for a “complete transformation”. Elliots in Prestwick will be given a new brand and feature live sport and entertainment seven days a week. The bar and restaurant shut its doors on Sunday, with bosses planning to reopen at Easter as Vic’s  The Vine. Buzzworks, who have operated Elliots as their flagship in the town, say the rebrand will be split into two halves. Managing director Kenny Blair said: “It’s essential to evolve within the hospitality industry and look at innovative ways to create new and exciting concepts for our customers. “Our work to reincarnate Elliots is part of our wider growth strategy, both benefiting the local community and Scotland’s hospitality industry.” Vic’s  The Vine will feature a -cover restaurant called The Vine serving food from breakfast until late. The bar will be called Vic’s and will be a “modern take on a traditional bar”, featuring sport and entertainment. Weekend opening hours will remain at .am.  Designer Jim Hamilton is leading the project, which will include a new glass roof in part of the bar. A new kitchen boasting a churrasco BBQ pit is also planned. Bosses say Vic’s will be the first venue in Ayrshire to serve fresh, unpasteurised tank beer straight from the brewery. Kenny added: “We’ve seen an appetite in the industry for more cool and modern pubs and, similarly to our T-Bar in Ayr, Vic’s will be a traditional bar with a twist. “This will both suit the local market and sit alongside our excellent new restaurant offering in Prestwick. “Our vision is to create the best day-to-night venue in Scotland and we are confident Vic’s  The Vine will match those expectations.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrPrestwickAyr News

story: NewsWoman wielded air rle and metal pole during rammy at Ayrshire houseThe -year-old admitted shoving the barrel of the rle into the home.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAyr Sherf Court "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA weapon wielding woman terried homeowners as she smashed windows during a violent air rle spree. Danielle Smith, , used a metal pole to shatter windows of a home on Ness Glen Road, Dalmellington on November , . But she didn’t act alone as Smith was spotted alongside a male when the pair terried their targets inside. Ayr Sherf Court heard he appeared to be carrying a black air rle. But Smith, of Castle Croft, Dalmellington, admitted shoving the barrel of the rle into the home. And the victims inside cowered in fear as they could hear Smith shouting “Get out here, get our here.” CCTV footage captured the pair on their threatening violent spree. Almost every window in the home had been smashed and holes in the windows were consistent with shots of the rle. Blood smears were spotted on the living room window. Police were called and discovered the metal pole used by Smith the following morning. A search warrant in Smith’s home uncovered pellets for an air rle in a box within her bedroom. But she told officers that the other person had been carrying the gun and she had never seen the gun before. She also stated that she threw the metal pole away as she believed the other person would have used it. Solicitor Steven Maxwell told the court he had viewed the footage. The lawyer commented: “It’s quite clear that she was quite literally in his stead and following him. “She cannot provide the court any reasonable explanation of how she managed to get herself in this situation but she was using and abusing drink and illegal substances. “At the time she would have followed this man where-ever he went. “If you fly with the crows, you get shot with them. Mr Maxwell said that Smith has “managed to turn her le around”. He added: “The young woman who appears before you is a very dferent woman. “She understands the seriousness of this.” Sherf Scott Pattison told Smith: “My first thought was to send you to jail for this shameful behaviour and very serious nature. “However I’m going to draw back from that because of your current progress in the community payback order. “I’m told by the social work department that you’re doing well. “You’re currently free from substance and alcohol misuse which is the big thing. “Butyou transgress, you’ll go straight to jail and it’ll be for a signicant period.” Smith admitted behaving in a threatening or abusive manner and, whilst acting with another, shouted, did kick and strike the door with a metal pole, point the barrel of an air rle into the home and smash windows.
